org.jtrim2.swing.component

Class TransformedImageDisplay<ImageAddress>

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent
          • org.jtrim2.swing.component.Graphics2DComponent
            • org.jtrim2.swing.component.AsyncRenderingComponent
              • org.jtrim2.swing.component.TransformedImageDisplay<ImageAddress>
  • Type Parameters:
    ImageAddress - the type of the address of the image to be displayed. That is, the input of the image query.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BasicTransformedImageDisplay

    public abstract class TransformedImageDisplay<ImageAddress>
extends AsyncRenderingComponent
    Defines a Swing component which is able to display an image applying a series of user defined transformations.

    There are three kind of properties you need to specify for this component:

    • The address of the image to be displayed. The address will be specified for the query used to retrieve the image. So the address can be any type, for example: java.net.URI. The address can be set by the imageAddress property.
    • The AsyncDataQuery used to retrieve the image. The image is retrieved by the address specified previously. The query can be set by the imageQuery property. methods.
    • The transformations which will be used to transform the image retrieved by the image query. The first transformation must be added by a call to the addFirstStep() method subsequent transformations must be added through this step through the TransformationStepPos interface. The addFirstStep method is recommended to be called by the constructor of the extending class, which ensures that no-one else might call this method successfully.

    Note that this component is an TransformedImageDisplay and relies on an AsyncRendererFactory. Therefore it must be set before displaying this component, either by passing an AsyncRendererFactory to the appropriate constructor or by setting it later.

    An example implementation which contains a single template transformation is shown here: 

     class SampleDisplay<ImageAddress>
 extends
         TransformedImageDisplay<ImageAddress> {
     private final TransformationStepDef defaultStep;

     public SampleDisplay(AsyncRendererFactory asyncRenderer) {
         super(asyncRenderer);

         defaultStep = addFirstStep();
         defaultStep.setTransformation(new ImageTransformationStep() {
             @Override
             public TransformedImage render(
                     CancellationToken cancelToken,
                     TransformationStepInput input,
                     BufferedImage offeredBuffer) {
                 BufferedImage inputImage = input.getInputImage().getImage();
                 if (inputImage == null) {
                     return new TransformedImage(null, null);
                 }

                 int destWidth = input.getDestinationWidth();
                 int destHeight = input.getDestinationHeight();
                 if (offeredBuffer == null
                         || offeredBuffer.getWidth() != destWidth
                         || offeredBuffer.getHeight() != destHeight) {
                     offeredBuffer = new BufferedImage(destWidth, destHeight, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_ARGB);
                 }

                 Graphics2D g = offeredBuffer.createGraphics();
                 try {
                     // Draw something to the output based on the input.
                     // The input you want is most likely the "inputImage".
                 } finally {
                     g.dispose();
                 }
                 return new TransformedImage(offeredBuffer, null);
             }
         });
     }

     public final TransformationStepPos getDefaultStep() {
         return defaultStep.getPosition();
     }
 }
    You may add subsequent transformations to this component by using the TransformationStepPos returned by the getDefaultStep method. Transformations can be added either after or before the initial transformation.

    The thread-safety property of this component is the same as with any other Swing components. That is, instances of this class can be accessed only from the AWT Event Dispatch Thread. Note however that MutableProperty and PropertySource instances can be read by any thread (even concurrently with writes to the property).

    • Constructor Detail

      • TransformedImageDisplay

        public TransformedImageDisplay()
        Creates a new TransformedImageDisplay without setting the AsyncRendererFactory to be used. Therefore the setAsyncRenderer must be called before displaying the component.

      • TransformedImageDisplay

        public TransformedImageDisplay(AsyncRendererFactory asyncRenderer)
        Creates a new TransformedImageDisplay using an AsyncRenderer created by the specified AsyncRendererFactory. Note however, that if you pass null for the argument of this constructor, you still have to call the setAsyncRenderer method before displaying the component.
        Parameters:
        asyncRenderer - the AsyncRendererFactory to be used to render this component. This argument can be null, in which case, the AsyncRendererFactory must be set later by the setAsyncRenderer method.

        Adds a listener which is to be notified after the transformation applied to retrieved image is changed.
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener whose run method is called on change. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the ListenerRef which might be used to remove the currently added listener. This method never returns null.

      • tmpBufferReferenceType

        public MutableProperty<ReferenceType> tmpBufferReferenceType()
        Returns the property defining the reference type to use for temporary buffers passed for transformations. That is, the offered buffer passed to the ImageTransformationStep.render method is cached and will be referenced according to this property.

        Note that setting this property does not necessarily takes effect until the currently cached buffers disappear from memory. Therefore, it is recommended to set this property before any rendering takes place: immediately after creating this component.

        The value of this property cannot be null.

        Returns:
        the property defining the reference type to use for temporary buffers passed for transformations. This method never returns null.

      • displayedPointTransformer

        public final PropertySource<ImagePointTransformer> displayedPointTransformer()
        Returns the property defining the coordinate transformation between image coordinates and display coordinates according to the currently displayed image.

        The source coordinate system of the returned transformation is the coordinate system of the source image and destination coordinate system is the coordinate system of this component. That is, transforming a coordinate from the source coordinates to the destination coordinate will transform the location of a pixel on the source image to the location of that pixel on this component. Note that the result may lay outside this component's bounds.

        This method always return the coordinate transformation according what is currently displayed on this component which may differ from the one which could be deduced from the currently set properties.

        Returns:
        the coordinate transformation between image coordinates and display coordinates according to the currently displayed image. This method never returns null but the value of the returned property can be null if it is not yet available.

      • imageMetaData

        public final PropertySource<ImageMetaData> imageMetaData()
        Returns the property containing the meta-data of the last retrieved image. The value of the returned property can be null if it is not available. Note that if this component is never displayed, no attempt will be made to fetch the image, therefore the value of this property will always return null.

        The value of this property can be null, if the meta-data is not available.

        Returns:
        the meta-data of the last retrieved image. This method never returns null but the value of the returned property can be null if it is not yet available.

      • imageShown

        public final PropertySource<java.lang.Boolean> imageShown()
        Returns the property defining if this component is currently displaying an image which was fetched from the currently set image query and address or not. This is also true if there was an error fetching the image and something was rendered instead of it.

        The value of this property cannot be null.

        Returns:
        the property defining if this component is currently displaying an image which was fetched from the currently set image query and address or not. This method never returns null and the value of the returned property is never null. In case the image from the currently set query is being displayed on this component, the value of the property is true, otherwise false.

      • oldImageHideTime

        public final MutableProperty<TimeDuration> oldImageHideTime()
        Returns the property which defines how much time must elapse after a previously shown image must be cleared from this component after changing the source image. That is, setting this property prevents the user to see the previous image shown for a long time, if the new image takes too much time to be displayed.

        The value of this property cannot be null.

        Returns:
        the property which defines how much time must elapse after a previously shown image must be cleared from this component after changing the source image. This method never returns null and the value of this property cannot be null.

      • longRenderingTimeout

        public final MutableProperty<TimeDuration> longRenderingTimeout()
        Returns the property which defines the time duration which is considered long for rendering this component. After this timeout elapses, the displayLongRenderingState method will be called periodically to render something (e.g.: progress or a "please wait" text) on this component.

        The value of this property can be null, which means that the value of this property is infinite. This is similar to setting this property to an extremely long duration (like years) except that the "infinite" case is implemented more efficiently.

        Returns:
        the property which defines the time duration which is considered long for rendering this component. This method never returns null but its value can be null if the timeout is to be considered infinite.

      • getTimeSinceImageChange

        public final long getTimeSinceImageChange(java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeunit)
        Returns the time since the source image of this component has been changed in the given time unit. This can either occur due to changing the image address or due to changing the image query.
        Parameters:
        timeunit - the time unit in which to result is to be returned. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the time since the source image of this component has been changed
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified argument is null

      • getTimeSinceLastImageShow

        public final long getTimeSinceLastImageShow(java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeunit)
        Returns the time since the last rendering of this component in the given time unit. This method only cares about image retrieval and image transformation, simply calling repaint has no effect on this method.
        Parameters:
        timeunit - the time unit in which to result is to be returned. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the time since the last rendering of this component
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified argument is null

      • imageAddress

        public final MutableProperty<ImageAddress> imageAddress()
        Returns the address of the image to be passed to the current image imageQuery().

        You may set this property to null and if it is null, no image will be displayed by this component. That is, if this property is null, this component will be painted with the background color of this component. Note: When the image query is null, the image address property must also be null.

        Returns:
        the address of the image to be passed to the current image imageQuery(). This method never returns null.

      • imageQuery

        public final MutableProperty<AsyncDataQuery<? super ImageAddress,? extends ImageResult>> imageQuery()
        Returns the image query used to retrieve the image to be displayed. The image provided by the image query will be transformed by the applied transformations.

        You may set this property to null and if it is null, no image will be displayed by this component. That is, if this property is null, this component will be painted with the background color of this component.

        Note: When the image query is null, the image address property must also be null.

        Returns:
        the image query property used to retrieve the image to be displayed. This method never returns null.

      • imageSource

        public final PropertySource<AsyncDataLink<? extends ImageResult>> imageSource()
        Returns the current source of image to be displayed by this component.

        This property can be null, in which case no image will be displayed by this component.

        Returns:
        the current source of image to be displayed by this component. This method never returns null.

      • onRenderingError

        protected void onRenderingError(BasicRenderingArguments renderingArgs,
                                java.awt.image.BufferedImage drawingSurface,
                                java.lang.Throwable exception)
        Called when an exception occurred while trying to retrieve the image or during rendering the image. This method may update the specified drawing surface.

        This method is called in the context of the AsyncRenderer of this component and may do some more expensive computation without blocking the input of the user.

        This method may be overridden in subclasses. The default implementation displays the exception message in the upper left corner of the drawing surface (which is the upper left corner of this component).

        Parameters:
        renderingArgs - the properties of this component at the time when the rendering has been requested. This argument cannot be null.
        drawingSurface - the BufferedImage which needs to be updated to display the error. This argument cannot be null.
        exception - the exception describing the reason of failure. Note that, this exception might have causes (and suppressed exceptions) which need to be inspected to fully understand the causes.

      • addLazyTransformationUpdater

        protected final void addLazyTransformationUpdater(java.lang.Runnable updaterTask)
        Adds a task to be run just before the applied transformations are collected for the renderer. This method is intended to allow subclasses to lazily build and set their transformations via TransformationStepDef.setTransformation.

        Subclasses should also consider using an UpdateTaskExecutor to add tasks via this method.

        Parameters:
        updaterTask - the Runnable whose run method is to be executed before actually collecting the applied transformations to the renderer. This argument cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified task is null

      • addFirstStep

        protected final TransformationStepDef addFirstStep()
        Adds the first transformation step used to transform the source image. Subclasses should call this method to add the first step for transforming the source image and later use TransformationStepDef.getPosition() to apply additional transformations before or after the first transformation step.

        This method may only be called once and it is recommended for subclasses to call this method in the constructor.

        Returns:
        the first transformation step used to transform the source image. This method never returns null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this method was attempted to be called more than once

      • paintDefault

        protected final void paintDefault(RenderingState state,
                                  java.awt.Graphics2D g)
        Clears the passed Graphics2D object with currently specified background color and does some other bookkeeping required by this component.
        Overrides:
        paintDefault in class AsyncRenderingComponent
        Parameters:
        state - the state of the current asynchronous rendering, or null if there is no rendering in progress
        g - the Graphics2D object to be cleared with the background color. This argument cannot be null.

      • displayLongRenderingState

        protected void displayLongRenderingState(java.awt.Graphics2D g,
                                         MultiAsyncDataState dataStates)
        Called when the rendering is still in progress and a given timeout elapsed. This method may update the display with addition information. Note however, that this method is called on the AWT Event Dispatch Thread and as such, should not do expensive computations.

        This method may be overridden in subclasses. The default implementation display some information of the image to be loaded and the current progress.

        Parameters:
        g - the Graphics2D to which this method need to draw to. This argument cannot be null. This method does not need to preserve the graphic context.
        dataStates - the current state of the image retrieving and rendering process. This state contains the state of the image retrieval process and all the applied transformations. This argument can never be null but can contain null states.
